    • Constructor Detail

      • Map

        public Map(javax.swing.JFrame frame,
           java.awt.Graphics2D g2d,
           Tile[] tiles,
           int mapWidth,
           int mapHeight,
           java.lang.String name)
        Constructor The constructor automatically duplicates all of the blueprinted tiles given in the Tile[] in to the needed shape of a map. The spriteSize is also taken from the first Tile in the array. The prupose of all of this is because having tons of tile data means nothing, by instantiating each individual tile, each tile becomes unique and can be accessed with its own specific properties.
        Parameters:
        frame - - A JFrame that the graphics will be dsiplayed on (The window)
        g2d - - The Graphics2D object that will be used to disaplay images on the JFrame
        tiles - - An array of tile blueprints which will be set up in the map for display in game.
        mapWidth - - An int identifying the width of the map in tiles
        mapHeight - - An int identifying the height of an array in tiles
        name - - A String which identifies the map, this is strictly a user identifier, it isn't used in any logic

    • Method Detail

      • render

        public void render(javax.swing.JFrame frame,
                   java.awt.Graphics2D g2d,
                   int xx,
                   int yy)
        The Render method goes to each tile in the specified map and renders it at a specific location. It also renders any mobs from each tile. These mobs start at the tile position, but when their x or y moves it is relative to the tile and does appear moving on the world map. About the 1D Array: The map is a one dimensional array of individual unique Tiles. In order to put these tiles in the correct spot, relative to how it was designed in the map database, a special way in moving around the array was needed. Using this specific way, a one dimensional array can be used instead of 2D, which saves space and optimizes the framerate of the game, allowing for larger more complicated maps. x + y * width
        Parameters:
        frame - - The JFrame which the map will be rendered in (The window)
        g2d - - The Graphics2D object wich is used to display images
        xx - - An offset in the x direction which moves the map around
        yy - - An offset in the y direction which moves the map around. Offsets are used to render a piece of a map in the window at a time to indicate placement in the world.

      • accessTile

        public Tile accessTile(int index)
        As the method name implies, access the tile at a specific index in the map The map is in a 1D array, so think x + y * width of the map when accessing the tile.
        Parameters:
        index - - An int of total x + y * width of the map to access a tile
        Returns:
        - A Tile which is accessed and can be changed

      • getMaxX

        public int getMaxX(int screenWidth)
        Get the maximum x value the player could move to in the map. maxX is the right border, unlike y, when X goes up, x goes right. Always gives back the opposite number found
        Parameters:
        screenWidth - - The width of the window screen given at the start of the Game
        Returns:
        - The maximum or minimum int x value

      • getMinX

        public int getMinX()

      • getMaxY

        public int getMaxY(int screenHeight)
        Get the maximum y value the player could move to in the map. maxY is the bottom edge, as Y goes down, the y value goes up. Always gives back the opposite number found
        Parameters:
        screenHeight - - The height of the window screen given at the start of the Game
        Returns:
        - The maximum or minimum int y value

        public int getMinY()
